choices.text: Twisted ovarian cyst

questions.text: A young female presents with acute abdominal pain and history of 1½ months amenorrhoea, on USG examination there is collection of fluid in the pouch of douglas and empty gestational sac seen in the adnexa. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ectopic Pregnancy

 

  • Ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tubes.
  • It can present with acute abdominal pain, amenorrhea, and signs of internal bleeding, such as fluid collection in the pouch of Douglas, which is the lowest point of the peritoneal cavity in women and can accumulate blood in cases of internal hemorrhage.
  • An empty gestational sac in the adnexa, in the presence of a positive pregnancy test and these clinical signs, strongly suggests an ectopic pregnancy rather than a normal intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pelvic Hematocele: While the presence of fluid in the pouch of Douglas could indicate a hematocele (a collection of blood), this term alone does not specify the source of the bleeding. An ectopic pregnancy can cause a hematocele due to rupture and internal bleeding, but the term "pelvic hematocele" by itself does not diagnose the cause.

 

Option C. Threatened Abortion: Threatened abortion involves vaginal bleeding during early pregnancy with a closed cervical os and no passage of fetal tissue. The presence of an empty gestational sac could be seen in threatened abortion, but the acute pain and fluid in the pouch of Douglas are more concerning for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Twisted Ovarian Cyst: Ovarian torsion can present with acute abdominal pain and might be associated with fluid in the pelvic cavity due to inflammation or bleeding. However, the presence of amenorrhea and an empty gestational sac are more indicative of a pregnancy-related issue, such as an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a young woman with acute abdominal pain, amenorrhea, and ultrasound findings of an empty gestational sac and fluid collection in the pouch of Douglas, an ectopic pregnancy should be highly suspected.
  • This condition is a gynecological emergency requiring prompt diagnosis and management to prevent potentially life-threatening complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with neck pain and limited range of motion following a minor car accident. Radiologic examination reveals an abnormality in the apical ligament of the dens. This ligament is embryologically derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Notochord

 

  • The Apical Ligament of the dens, an important stabilizer of the cervical spine, is embryologically derived from the notochord.
  • In this clinical scenario, the patient's symptoms are likely related to trauma to the cervical spine, particularly involving the axis (C2) and its supporting structures.
  • The notochord gives rise to the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral discs and contributes to the formation of axial skeletal structures, including ligaments like the apical ligament of the dens.

 

 

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

 

Option A. Neural Tube: The neural tube is the precursor to the central nervous system, forming structures like the brain and spinal cord. While it is essential for the development of the nervous system, it does not give rise to the apical ligament of the dens.

 

Option B. Neural Crest:  Neural crest cells are a group of cells that arise from the border of the neural tube and migrate to various parts of the embryo. They contribute to the development of diverse structures, including peripheral nerves, melanocytes, and facial cartilage, but they do not form the apical ligament of the dens.

 

Option D. Neuropore: The neuropores are the openings at the ends of the neural tube during early embryonic development. The closure of the neuropores is critical in the formation of the central nervous system. The neuropores do not contribute to the development of the apical ligament of the dens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The apical ligament of the dens is a derivative of the notochord.
  • The notochord is an embryonic structure that provides signals for the development of the vertebral column and eventually forms the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs.
  • The apical ligament of the dens represents a remnant of the notochord.

choices.text: Hop on 1 foot
Use spoon effectively
Copy a square
Reliably catch a ball

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the paediatrician’s office for a routine check-up. His mother reports that he enjoys playing with other children and is good at communication. Which of the following developmental milestones is most concerning if not achieved by this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Use spoon effectively

 

  • Using a spoon effectively is a skill that children typically acquire by 18 months to 2 years.
  • Difficulty with this skill at 3 years of age may indicate a delay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hop on 1 foot: Hopping on one foot is a skill typically developed around 4 years of age, and its absence is not concerning at 3 years.

 

Option C. Copy a square: Copying a square is a more advanced fine motor skill expected to develop by 4 years of age.

 

Option D. Reliably catch a ball: Reliably catching a ball is a complex motor skill that is often developed after 3 years of age, and difficulty with this skill at 3 years is not concerning for a developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • By 3 years of age, children should be able to use a spoon effectively to feed themselves.

questions.text: In the context of Indian courts, which type of evidence is usually prioritized by the judiciary in making decisions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral Evidence

 

  • Oral evidence is more important than documentary evidence, as it permits cross-examination.
  • Documentary evidence is accepted by the Court only on oral testimony by the person concerned. Oral evidence may be direct/ indirect/ hearsay.
  • A medical opinion is subjective and subject to interpretation and further cross questioning.
  • Hence medical opinion in injury report, postmortem report, Age report, Medicolegal certificates etc are never admissible in court as document alone, they must be accompanied by the oral evidence of concerned Doctor.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Circumstantial evidence: It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness, but has a bearing upon other fact, e.g., in case of alleged murder of A by B at certain place on a particular day and time, the circumstantial evidence would be that C saw B with a knife on that day at that place, a few minutes before the murder. Circumstantial evidence requires the Court to draw logical inferences from the information presented. 

 

Option C. Documentary evidence: It includes all documents produced for the inspection of the Court. Documentary evidence is accepted in court only after oral testimony of the concerned person who prepared the document except in few cases (e.g. dying declaration, expert opinion expressed in a treatise, etc).

 

Option D. Hearsay evidence: It is any statement made by any person about what he did not personally witness, e.g., A gives evidence in the witness box stating that B had informed him that he had seen C committing a crime. Hearsay is generally not admissible in court because it does not allow for cross-examination. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Exception to oral evidence (where document alone is acceptable):
  1. Dying declaration
  2. Expert opinions expressed in a book
  3. Deposition of a medical witness taken in a lower court
  4. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding
  5. Statements by persons who cannot be called as itnesses: e.g. dead, untraceable etc.
  6. Report of certain government scientific experts:
    1. Chemical Examiner 
    2. Chief Controller of Explosives,
    3. Director of Fingerprint Bureau,
    4. Director of a Central Forensic Science Laboratory

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with 20 weeks pregnancy presents with bleeding per vaginum. On speculum examination, the os is open but no products have come out. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inevitable abortion

 

  • Inevitable abortion refers to a clinical situation where the signs and symptoms indicate that a miscarriage is certain to occur but has not yet completed.
  • Key features include vaginal bleeding, cramping, and dilation of the cervical os without the expulsion of the fetus or placenta.
  • The term "inevitable" is used because the cervical changes (specifically, the dilation of the os) suggest that the process of miscarriage has reached a point where it cannot be halted.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Missed abortion: This occurs when the fetus has died or failed to develop but is retained in the uterus, often without any significant bleeding or dilation of the cervical os. The diagnosis of missed abortion is usually made by ultrasound, showing no fetal heartbeat.

 

Option B. Incomplete abortion: Incomplete abortion is characterized by the passage of some, but not all, pregnancy tissues. There may be an open cervical os, but crucially, there would also be evidence of retained products of conception, which is not described in the scenario provided.

 

Option D. Complete abortion: Complete abortion refers to the situation where all products of conception have been expelled from the uterus, typically accompanied by relief of symptoms such as bleeding and cramping. The cervical os may begin to close following a complete abortion.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The presentation of vaginal bleeding, cramping, and an open cervical os without the passage of any pregnancy tissues at 20 weeks of gestation is indicative of an inevitable abortion, where the miscarriage process is irreversible but not yet complete.

questions.text: During an equipment check on an anesthesia machine, you are tasked with identifying and understanding the function of various components within the intermediate pressure system. Which of the following is a component of this system?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diameter index safety system

 

  • The Diameter index safety system (DISS) is part of the intermediate pressure system.
  • It prevents the misconnection of gas-specific hoses to the wrong gas pipeline supply outlets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pin index safety system: The Pin index safety system is a part of the high-pressure system of an anesthesia machine. It is designed to prevent the attachment of a cylinder containing the wrong type of gas to the machine.

 

Option B. Pressure reducing valve: A Pressure reducing valve (regulator) is also a part of the high-pressure system. It reduces the high pressure from a gas cylinder to a lower, more usable pressure for the anesthesia machine.

 

Option D. Rotameter: A Rotameter is a part of the low-pressure system and is used to control the flow of anesthesia gases from the machine to the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diameter index safety system is a component of the intermediate pressure system of an anesthesia machine, which is designed to ensure that gas-specific hoses are connected to the correct gas pipeline supply outlets.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents with gradual, progressive visual field loss in both eyes. Examination reveals increased intraocular pressure, cupping of the optic disc, and visual field testing shows arcuate scotoma. Which cell type in the retina is primarily affected in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ganglion cells

 

  • Ganglion cells are the final output neurons of the vertebrate retina.
  • They are primarily affected in glaucomatous optic atrophy, leading to characteristic optic nerve changes and visual field loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amacrine cells: Amacrine cells are interneurons in the retina that process visual information. They are not primarily affected in glaucomatous optic atrophy.

 

Option B. Bipolar cells: Bipolar cells are also interneurons in the retina and serve as a relay between photoreceptors and ganglion cells. They are not the initial cell type affected in glaucoma.

 

Option D. Rods and cones: Rods and cones are the photoreceptor cells in the retina responsible for light detection and image formation. They are not directly affected by the elevated intraocular pressure in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy primarily affects retinal ganglion cells, leading to their apoptosis and resulting in progressive optic nerve changes and visual field defects.

choices.text: Administration of single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery.
Skin closure with staples than with suture

questions.text: Which of the following steps has proven benefit in decreasing puerperal infection following cesarean section:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administration of single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery.

 

  • The administration of a single dose of prophylactic antibiotics, typically ampicillin or a first-generation cephalosporin, at the time of cesarean delivery, has been well-documented to significantly reduce the risk of postoperative infections, including puerperal (postpartum) infections.
  • This practice is supported by extensive research and is a standard recommendation in obstetric guidelines.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Non-closure of peritoneum: This refers to not suturing the peritoneal layers (visceral and parietal) after a cesarean section. While some studies suggest that non-closure can reduce operating time and postoperative pain, its impact on decreasing puerperal infection is not as direct or significant as antibiotic prophylaxis.

 

Option B. Single layer uterine closure: This involves closing the uterine incision with a single layer of sutures rather than the traditional double layer. This method may reduce operating time and use of suture material, but its effect on reducing puerperal infections is not as clear-cut or substantiated as the use of prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Option D. Skin closure with staples rather than with suture: The choice between staples and sutures for skin closure after a cesarean section may affect wound healing, cosmesis, and patient satisfaction, but neither method has been definitively proven to be superior in reducing the rate of puerperal infections when compared directly to the administration of prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The administration of a single dose of prophylactic antibiotics, such as ampicillin or a first-generation cephalosporin, at the time of cesarean delivery is a proven strategy to decrease the risk of puerperal infections, aligning with evidence-based recommendations to enhance postoperative outcomes and maternal health.

choices.text: R. prowazekii and R. typhi
R. typhi and R. rickettsii
R. prowazekii and R. rickettsii
R. rickettsii and C. burnetii

questions.text: In the laboratory setting, researchers are employing various serological tests to distinguish between different rickettsial species. The Weil-Felix reaction, historically known as the Neil Mosser reaction, is utilized for this purpose. Which of the following pairs of Rickettsiae species can be differentiated using the Weil-Felix reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) R. prowazekii and R. typhi

 

  • The Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test that was traditionally used to diagnose rickettsial infections by detecting agglutinating antibodies against certain Proteus antigens that cross-react with rickettsial antigens.
  • R. prowazekii and R. typhi are known to give positive Weil-Felix reactions due to cross-reactivity with OX-19 and OX-2 antigens of certain Proteus strains. However, this test has limitations in sensitivity and specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. R. typhi and R. rickettsii: The Weil-Felix reaction is not reliable for differentiating between these two, as R. rickettsii does not consistently produce a positive reaction.

 

Option C. R. prowazekii and R. rickettsii: R. rickettsii typically does not react in the Weil-Felix test.

 

Option D. R. rickettsii and C. burnetii: The Weil-Felix reaction is not used to differentiate between Rickettsia rickettsii and Coxiella burnetii, the latter being the causative agent of Q fever and not a rickettsial species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neil mooser reaction is done to differentiate epidemic typhus R. prowazekii which gives a negative tunica reaction and endemic typhus (R. typhi) which gives a positive tunica reaction.

choices.text: To determine the viability of sperm
To assess the quality of cervical mucous
To evaluate the process of ovulation
To examine the uterine lining

questions.text: An infertile couple is being evaluated for infertility. They are advised to take a post coital test. What is the purpose of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To assess the quality of cervical mucous

 

  • The post-coital test (PCT), also known as the Sims-Huhner test, is conducted to assess the interaction between sperm and cervical mucous after sexual intercourse.
  • This test is performed close to the time of ovulation, when cervical mucous is most receptive to sperm.
  • During the test, a sample of cervical mucous is examined under a microscope shortly after intercourse to observe the presence and motility of sperm within the mucous.
  • This helps to assess not only the ability of sperm to survive in the cervical mucous but also the quality of the cervical mucous in terms of its receptivity to sperm, which is crucial for successful fertilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To determine the viability of sperm: While the post-coital test does involve observing sperm in the cervical mucous, its primary purpose is not to assess sperm viability in isolation. Semen analysis is the standard test for evaluating sperm count, motility, and morphology.

 

Option C. To evaluate the process of ovulation: The post-coital test does not directly evaluate ovulation. Other methods, such as measuring basal body temperature, ultrasound examinations, and blood tests for hormone levels, are used to assess ovulation.

 

Option D. To examine the uterine lining: The examination of the uterine lining, or endometrium, is not the goal of the post-coital test. Endometrial assessment is typically performed through ultrasound or more invasive procedures like hysteroscopy or endometrial biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The post-coital test is conducted to assess the interaction between sperm and cervical mucous following intercourse, specifically looking at how well sperm can survive and move within the cervical mucous.
  • This test helps to identify potential issues with cervical mucous that might impede sperm movement or survival, which could contribute to infertility.

choices.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy
Peritumour marking with dye

questions.text: In the procedure depicted, methylene blue is being injected peri-tumorally. This method is commonly used in which of the following surgical procedures for breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

 

  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy is used to identify the first lymph node(s) into which a tumor drains and to which cancer cells are most likely to spread from the primary tumor.
  • A dual tracer method using a blue dye and a radioactive or fluorescent dye helps in identifying sentinel nodes during surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tumour painting: Tumour painting refers to a surgical technique where a dye is applied directly to a tumor during surgery to help delineate its borders, which is not indicated in this scenario.

 

Option C. Breast tattooing: Breast tattooing involves marking the breast with a semi-permanent dye for identification and localization in future procedures or radiation therapy, not typically associated with the immediate identification of sentinel lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Peritumour marking with dye: Peritumour marking with dye is done for localization during surgery, but it does not typically involve identifying lymph nodes for biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sentinel lymph node biopsy is performed using a dual tracer method to identify the first lymph node(s) draining the area of a primary tumor in breast carcinoma, aiding in the assessment of cancer spread.

questions.text: Which type of pelvis is associated with increased incidence of ‘face to pubis’ delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthropoid pelvis

 

  • The anthropoid pelvis is characterized by its oval shape, with a longer anteroposterior diameter.
  • This shape can sometimes lead to a higher incidence of "face to pubis" deliveries, also known as face presentations, where the baby's face is the presenting part during delivery.
  • The elongated shape of the anthropoid pelvis may facilitate the engagement of the fetal head in a hyperextended position, leading to a face presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gynaecoid Pelvis: The gynaecoid pelvis is considered the classical female pelvis and is the most favorable for vaginal childbirth. It features a round pelvic inlet, wide and shallow pelvic cavity, and a well-rounded subpubic arch, facilitating the engagement, descent, and rotation of the fetal head in the most common occiput anterior position.

 

Option C. Android Pelvis: The android pelvis is more typically male-like with a heart-shaped inlet, narrow subpubic angle, and prominent ischial spines. These characteristics can make vaginal delivery more challenging due to the restricted space for the fetal head to navigate through the pelvis. It is more commonly associated with occiput posterior positions and potentially with other malpresentations, but not specifically with an increased incidence of face presentations.

 

Option D. Platypelloid Pelvis: The platypelloid or flat pelvis is characterized by a broad transverse diameter and shortened anteroposterior diameter, making it look kidney-shaped. This type of pelvis is less common and can complicate labor due to the limited anteroposterior space, but it does not have a specific association with "face to pubis" deliveries. Instead, it might be associated with transverse fetal positions due to the wider transverse space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anthropoid pelvis, with its oval shape and longer anteroposterior diameter, can be associated with an increased incidence of "face to pubis" deliveries due to the way it may affect fetal head engagement and presentation during labor.

choices.text: Defect is in Calcium Pump ATP 2A2 Gene
Histopathology Reveals Incomplete Acantholysis
Nails have Red & White Longitudinal Bands
Retinoids are treatment of choice

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with a recurrent history of vesiculopustular macerated plaques over the axilla as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is TRUE about the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Histopathology Reveals Incomplete Acantholysis

 

  • Hailey-Hailey disease is a genetic disorder characterized by recurrent blisters and erosions, primarily in intertriginous areas (such as the axillae and groin).
  • Histopathologically, the hallmark is incomplete acantholysis, which means that the connections between keratinocytes in the epidermis are partially lost, leading to blister formation.
  • Hailey-Hailey disease is characterized histologically by a "dilapidated brick wall" appearance due to incomplete acantholysis, where there is a loss of adhesion between individual keratinocytes within the epidermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defect is in Calcium Pump ATP 2A2 Gene:  This gene defect is associated with Darier's disease, another genetic skin disorder characterized by greasy keratotic papules in seborrheic areas and not typically with recurrent vesiculopustular lesions.

 

Option C. Nails have Red & White Longitudinal Bands: This is more characteristic of Darier's disease.

 

Option D. Retinoids are treatment of choice: While retinoids can be used in the management of Hailey-Hailey disease, they are not considered the first line of treatment. The management often includes corticosteroids, antibiotics for secondary infection, and sometimes surgery or laser therapy for more persistent lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hailey-Hailey disease is characterized by recurrent vesiculopustular lesions, particularly in areas of friction such as the axillae, with histopathological findings of incomplete acantholysis.

choices.text: Observe only as it is mostly physiological jaundice
Liver function tests and liver biopsy as it is mostly due to cholestasis

questions.text: A new-born is noted to have jaundice on the first day of life. The mother's blood type is O positive, and there are no signs of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phototherapy

 

  • Phototherapy is the treatment of choice for neonatal jaundice presenting on the first day of life when due to non-hemolytic causes, as it helps to reduce bilirubin levels. 

 

Option A. Observe only as it is mostly physiological jaundice: Observing the neonate without intervention is not appropriate as jaundice on the first day is not typically physiological and requires intervention.

 

Option B. Exchange transfusion: Exchange transfusion is reserved for severe jaundice or when there is evidence of hemolysis and high-risk factors for kernicterus.

 

Option C. Liver function tests and liver biopsy as it is mostly due to cholestasis: Liver function tests and biopsy are not first-line approaches for jaundice on the first day of life as they are invasive and not typically indicated without evidence of cholestatic jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neonatal jaundice presenting on the first day of life generally requires intervention with phototherapy, especially if related to non-hemolytic causes, as early treatment can prevent the development of severe hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus.

questions.text: Which of the following features indicates the presence of heart disease in pregnancy and which is not seen in normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Distended neck veins

 

  • Distended neck veins can indicate elevated central venous pressure, which might be a sign of heart failure or other cardiovascular diseases.
  • This is not a normal finding in pregnancy and should prompt further evaluation for potential heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exertional Dyspnea: While exertional dyspnea can be a symptom of heart disease, it is also a common and normal finding in pregnancy due to the increased metabolic demands and changes in respiratory physiology, making it less specific for heart disease.

 

Option C. Systemic Hypotension: Systemic hypotension is actually more common in pregnancy due to the vasodilatory effects of progesterone and the increased blood flow to the uterus and placenta. It's not typically indicative of heart disease in the absence of other symptoms.

 

Option D. Pedal Edema: Pedal edema is a common finding in normal pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, due to the increased blood volume and pressure from the enlarging uterus on the veins in the pelvis. While it can also be a symptom of heart disease, its presence alone in pregnancy is not usually indicative of cardiac pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Distended neck veins is a clinical feature that indicates the presence of heart disease in pregnancy and is not normally seen in healthy pregnant women.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male present with bony mass in the metaphyseal region of right knee with typical sun ray appearance and CT Scan of the chest reveals osteoblastic metastases. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically presents in the metaphyseal region of long bones, such as near the knee.
  • The "sun ray" or "sunburst" appearance on imaging is characteristic of osteosarcoma, which represents the periosteal reaction to the aggressive bone formation by the tumor.
  • The presence of osteoblastic metastases in the lungs on a CT scan is also consistent with osteosarcoma, as this type of cancer is known for its potential to metastasize to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma originates from cartilaginous tissue and usually presents as a slowly growing mass. It does not typically show a "sun ray" appearance on imaging.

 

Option C. Ewing’s sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is another primary bone cancer, more often seen in the diaphysis of long bones and in the pelvis. It is typically associated with an "onion skin" periosteal reaction, not a "sun ray" appearance.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that presents as a cartilage-capped bony outgrowth, usually on the metaphysis of long bones. It does not show a "sun ray" appearance or typical osteoblastic lung metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "sun ray" appearance on imaging, combined with the presence of osteoblastic metastases in the lungs and location in the metaphyseal region of the knee, strongly suggests a diagnosis of osteosarcoma.

choices.text: Severe acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency with abdominal pain and an episode of binge drinking, in shock with a BP of 70/50 mm Hg and HR of 115/min. The oxygen saturation of the patient is 70 mm Hg. The serum creatinine level was 2.4 mg/dL. The patient has a serum lipase of 400. What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe acute pancreatitis

 

  • Severe acute pancreatitis is characterized by abdominal pain, systemic signs of shock, and extensive pancreatic necrosis on imaging, which aligns with this patient's clinical picture.

 

Option A. Liver abscess: Liver abscess typically presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice; CT imaging would show a localized collection within the liver.

 

Option B. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis often presents with acute onset of abdominal pain and can be associated with alcohol intake but may not show extensive necrosis on CT, nor present with acute renal failure as in the given scenario.

 

Option C. Acute pyelonephritis: Acute pyelonephritis usually presents with flank pain, fever, and urinary symptoms; a CT scan may show changes in the kidneys but not the pancreas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of clinical signs of shock, history of alcohol misuse, elevated creatinine and lipase, along with CT findings of extensive pancreatic necrosis, indicates severe acute pancreatitis with organ failure.

questions.text: An elderly multiparous woman with intrauterine foetal death was admitted with strong labour pains. The patient suddenly goes in shock with cyanosis respiratory disturbances and pulmonary oedema. The most likely clinical diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amniotic Fluid Embolism

 

  • Amniotic Fluid Embolism (AFE) is a rare but serious and potentially fatal condition that occurs when amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enters the maternal bloodstream, typically during labor, delivery, or immediately postpartum.
  • It can lead to sudden cardiovascular collapse, respiratory distress, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), presenting as acute shock, cyanosis, and pulmonary edema, as described in the scenario.
  • AFE is a diagnosis of exclusion but should be strongly suspected in the described clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture of Uterus: Uterine rupture can lead to shock, but it is more commonly associated with severe abdominal pain and tenderness, loss of fetal station, and cessation of contractions. It doesn't typically present with the acute respiratory symptoms described.

 

Option B. Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): While CHF can lead to pulmonary edema and respiratory distress, it would not typically cause acute shock in the absence of a pre-existing condition or precipitating event, and it is less likely to present acutely in the context of labor.

 

Option D. Concealed Accidental Hemorrhage: Also known as concealed placental abruption, this condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, which can lead to shock. However, the hallmark signs include abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and often a hard, board-like abdomen. The sudden onset of respiratory distress and cyanosis is less characteristic than in amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amniotic fluid embolism is a potential cause of sudden onset shock, cyanosis, respiratory disturbances, and pulmonary edema in a pregnant woman during labor, especially in the context of intrauterine fetal death.

questions.text: A medical resident is participating in a forensic rotation and is presented with a challenging task. The resident needs to analyze a degraded blood sample collected from an old crime scene to confirm the presence of hemoglobin. Given the sample's condition, it's crucial to use a forensic test that can provide specific microscopic evidence to ensure the result's accuracy. The resident must select the most appropriate test to observe the characteristic findings that would confirm haemoglobin’s presence. Which test should the medical resident utilize to observe the characteristic pink feathery crystals that confirm the presence of hemoglobin in the degraded blood sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Takayama test

 

  • The Takayama test is a forensic chemical test specifically designed to confirm the presence of hemoglobin in blood samples.
  • This test is known for producing characteristic pink feathery crystals, known as hemochromogen crystals, when the sample reacts with pyridine and sodium hydroxide.
  • These distinctive microscopic findings provide a reliable indication of hemoglobin's presence, making the Takayama test particularly useful in forensic analysis of blood, even in degraded samples.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teichmann test: This test also confirms the presence of hemoglobin but results in the formation of brownish crystals of hemin chloride, not pink feathery crystals.

 

Option C. Barbario’s test: This is not a recognized standard test for the detection of hemoglobin in forensic science.

 

Option D. Xanthoproteic test: This test is used to detect the presence of aromatic amino acids in proteins by producing a yellow color upon reaction with nitric acid and is not specific to hemoglobin detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)
  • Teichmann’s - Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Takayama test - Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)
  • Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)
  • Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient is undergoing a surgical procedure under general anesthesia and is breathing spontaneously. Which breathing circuit should be used to facilitate spontaneous ventilation in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mapleson A

 

  • Mapleson A, also known as the Magill circuit, is well-suited for patients who are spontaneously breathing as it allows for efficient removal of carbon dioxide and requires a fresh gas flow rate roughly equivalent to the patient's minute volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mapleson B:  Mapleson B is not commonly used in clinical practice and is not designed for efficient spontaneous ventilation.

 

Option C. Mapleson C: Mapleson C, or the Waters circuit, is often used in the recovery room setting due to its ability to provide a reservoir of fresh gas during the expiratory phase but is less efficient than Mapleson A for spontaneous breathing during anesthesia.

 

Option D. Mapleson D: Mapleson D, known as the Bain coaxial system, is generally preferred for controlled ventilation, where the ventilator controls the patient's breaths, rather than spontaneous breathing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mapleson A (Magill circuit) is the breathing circuit of choice for patients who are undergoing general anesthesia and are spontaneously breathing, due to its efficient carbon dioxide clearance.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman with fibroid uterus develops acute pain in abdomen with low grade fever and mild leucocytosis at 28 weeks. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red degeneration of fibroid

 

  • Red degeneration, also known as necrobiosis, is a common complication of fibroids during pregnancy.
  • It occurs due to the rapid growth of the fibroid outpacing its blood supply, leading to degeneration.
  • The presentation typically includes acute, localized abdominal pain often associated with tenderness over the fibroid, and it can be accompanied by low-grade fever and a mild increase in white blood cell count due to the inflammatory response.
  • Red degeneration is particularly common in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preterm Labour: While preterm labor can present with abdominal pain and systemic symptoms, it is usually characterized by regular uterine contractions and changes in the cervix (dilatation, effacement, or both). The presence of fibroids and the specific nature of the pain described make red degeneration a more likely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Torsion of Fibroid: Torsion of a pedunculated fibroid can cause acute abdominal pain and can be associated with nausea and vomiting. While it could present similarly to red degeneration, torsion is less common and typically presents with more severe and sudden pain.

 

Option D. Infection of Fibroid: Infection within a fibroid is extremely rare and would likely present with more significant signs of infection, such as high fever and more pronounced leukocytosis, than described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Red degeneration of fibroids is a likely cause of acute abdominal pain, low-grade fever, and mild leukocytosis in a pregnant woman with a known fibroid uterus.

questions.text: Match the following according to the classification of arrangement of muscle fibres with their example for each type?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1- b, 2- a, 3- d, 4- c 

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Different types of arrangement of muscle fibres shown in image:

 

 

  1. Parallel Arrangement:
    • Muscle fibers run parallel to the long axis of the muscle.
    • Example: Biceps brachii
  2. Pennate Arrangement:
    • Muscle Fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon, forming a feather-like pattern.
    • Example: Rectus Femoris
  3. Cruciate Arrangement: 
    • Muscle fibres having 2 sets, which cross each other
    • Example: Sternocleidomastoid
  4. Spiral/ Twisted: 
    • Muscle fibres having only 1 set in which upper fibres runs down & lower fibres runs upside in between attachments.
    • Example: Latissimus Dorsi & Pectoralis Major

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arrangement of muscle fibre direction is important for identification of muscle during surgery & cadaveric images in exams.
  • Biceps brachii shows Parallel arrangement, Rectus femoris shows Pennate arrangement, Sternocleidomastoid shows Cruciate arrangement & Latissimus dorsi  shows Spiral arrangement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a 3-month history of progressive breathlessness and dyspnea was evaluated. A chest X-ray revealed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the lung. A lobectomy was performed, and histopathological examination of the specimen produced the images shown. Based on these images, identify the infectious agent and the number of layers present in the cyst structure:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus with 2 layers

 

  • The histopathology images show a cystic structure that is characteristic of Echinococcus granulosus infection, which causes hydatid disease. Echinococcus cysts are known to have two principal layers: an outer acellular laminated layer and an inner germinal layer.
  • The outer layer is thick and elastic, while the inner layer is nucleated and produces the protoscolices and brood capsules.
  • This cystic structure is typical for Echinococcus, which can cause cavitary lesions in the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba with 1 layer: Entamoeba histolytica causes amebic liver abscesses, which do not have a cystic structure with multiple layers in human tissues.

 

Option C. Lung fluke with 1 layer: Lung flukes, such as Paragonimus westermani, can cause cavitary lung lesions, but they do not form cystic structures with multiple layers like Echinococcus.

 

Option D. Strongyloides with 2 layers: Strongyloides stercoralis typically causes a pulmonary infection characterized by larval migration through the lung, not by forming layered cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid cyst - The cyst wall of hydatid cyst is bilayered (ectocyst and endocyst). There is also a host derived outer pericyst layer.

choices.text: Injection of PGF 2α (Prostaglandin F2 alpha)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman para 6 delivers vaginally following normal labour with spontaneous delivery of an intact placenta. Excessive bleeding continues, despite manual exploration, bimanual massage, intravenous oxytocin and administration of 0.2 mg methergin IV, which one of the following would be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Injection of PGF 2α (Prostaglandin F2 alpha)

 

  • Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF 2α) is a potent uterotonic agent that can be used when bleeding persists despite oxytocin and ergot derivatives like methergine.
  • It causes intense myometrial contractions, thereby helping to control bleeding.
  • It is considered a second-line agent due to its side effects, but it can be highly effective in managing refractory postpartum hemorrhage and is less invasive than surgical options, making it a suitable next step in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Packing the uterus: Uterine packing can be considered in cases of severe postpartum hemorrhage when other measures have failed, but it is generally not the first choice due to the potential for infection and the fact that it may not effectively address the underlying cause of the hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Immediate hysterectomy: An immediate hysterectomy is considered a last-resort option for uncontrollable postpartum hemorrhage when all other measures have failed and the woman's life is at risk. It results in the loss of fertility, so it's typically reserved for life-threatening situations where other interventions have been unsuccessful.

 

Option C. Bilateral internal iliac ligation: Ligation of the internal iliac (hypogastric) arteries can reduce pelvic blood flow and help control bleeding. However, this surgical procedure is more invasive than pharmacological interventions and is generally considered only after less invasive measures have failed and before proceeding to hysterectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When managing a case of postpartum hemorrhage that is unresponsive to first-line interventions such as oxytocin and methergine, the next step should include considering the administration of PGF 2α due to its potent uterotonic effects, before proceeding to more invasive surgical options.
  • This approach allows for the potential control of bleeding while preserving the uterus and fertility.

choices.text: Bone Ingrowth/ overgrowth over the surface of the stem
Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone
Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal
Adhesion between the stem and bone due to adhesive properties of the stem

questions.text: In uncemented arthroplasty of the hip, the stem remains attached to the bone by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bone Ingrowth/ overgrowth over the surface of the stem

 

  • Uncemented arthroplasty relies on the biological fixation of the prosthesis to the bone.
  • Bone ingrowth or ongrowth refers to the process where new bone grows into the surface of a prosthesis, which often has a porous or textured surface to facilitate this process.
  • Over time, this leads to stabilization of the prosthesis as it becomes integrated into the bony architecture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone: Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone While mechanical interlock may play a role initially in stability, long-term fixation in uncemented arthroplasty is primarily due to biological fixation through bone ingrowth.

 

Option C. Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal: Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal Press-fitting is a technique used during the surgical placement of an uncemented prosthesis to provide initial stability. However, the definitive and long-term stability comes from bone ingrowth into the prosthesis.

 

Option D. Adhesion between the stem and bone due to adhesive properties of the stem: Adhesion is not the primary mechanism of attachment in uncemented arthroplasty. The stem does not have adhesive properties; rather, it is designed to allow bone to grow into or onto it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary method of fixation in uncemented arthroplasty of the hip is through bone ingrowth or ongrowth over the surface of the prosthesis.
  • This biological fixation provides a stable and durable attachment as opposed to cemented arthroplasty, which relies on the use of bone cement for immediate fixation.

choices.text: Junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu
Junction of the outer two-thirds and inner one-third of the greater cornu
Middle of the greater cornu

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting an autopsy on an adult victim of suspected hanging. Examination of the neck is particularly focused on the hyoid bone, as fractures here can be indicative of the cause of death. In cases of hanging, where is a fracture of the hyoid bone most likely to be found?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater

 

  • Hyoid fractures are more common in manual strangulation > Hanging > Strangulation. 
  • 3 types:
  1. Inward compression fracture-seen in manual strangulation
  2. Anteroposterior compression fracture-seen in hanging
  3. Avulsion or tug or traction fracture 
  • Most common site of hyoid fracture is junction of the outer 1/3rd and inner 2/3rd of greater cornu.
  • Fractures are rare below 40 years because of the elasticity of the cartilage and mobility of the joints. The fracture is common in persons above 40 years and involves the great horns, at the junction of inner two-thirds and outer one-third.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Junction of the outer two-thirds and inner one-third of the greater cornu: Less commonly involved in fractures due to hanging. 

 

Option C. Middle of the greater cornu: This area is stronger and less likely to be fractured in hanging.

 

Option D. Middle of the body: The body of the hyoid bone is less commonly fractured in hanging compared to the junction of the greater cornu.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The common anatomical site of hyoid bone fracture in cases of hanging, is most often at the junction of the outer one-third and inner two-thirds of the greater cornu.

choices.text: It is the most common indication for primary csesarean delivery
The cervix should be atleast 2 cm dilated for diagnosis of dystocia
Dystocia can be due to abnormality in power, passage and passenger

questions.text: All are true regarding dystocia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The cervix should be at least 2 cm dilated for the diagnosis of dystocia.

 

  • The statement about the ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists) recommending that the cervix should be at least 2 cm dilated for the diagnosis of dystocia is not accurate.
  • The ACOG has provided updated guidelines on the diagnosis of labor dystocia, focusing on a more individualized approach to labor progress.
  • The traditional "Friedman's curve," which suggested a specific rate of cervical dilation, has been revised to acknowledge a wider range of normal labor progression patterns.
  • The emphasis is on avoiding the diagnosis of labor dystocia based solely on the cervical dilation reaching a specific measurement at a specific time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dystocia is difficult labor: This statement is true. Dystocia describes a situation where labor is prolonged or not progressing as expected, making it difficult.

 

Option B. It is the most common indication for primary caesarean delivery: This is correct. Dystocia is a leading reason for performing a primary cesarean delivery, as difficult or stalled labor can pose risks to both the mother and the fetus.

 

Option D. Dystocia can be due to abnormality in power, passage, and passenger: This statement is also true. The causes of dystocia can be classified based on issues with the power (uterine contractions), the passage (birth canal and pelvis), or the passenger (the fetus). Each of these factors can contribute to labor difficulties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ACOG does not specify a cervical dilation of at least 2 cm for the diagnosis of dystocia.
  • Instead, the diagnosis should be based on a comprehensive assessment of labor progress, taking into account the individual variability of labor patterns.

choices.text: Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby
Perform serum VDRL of the baby
Perform CSF VDRL of the baby

questions.text: A 29-years-old pregnant female's routine investigations showed VDRL positive with 1:16 titres. TPHA was also positive. The pregnant female was adequately treated with injection benzathine penicillin. What is the next step of management for the baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform serum VDRL of the baby

 

  • A baby born to a mother who has been diagnosed with syphilis and treated during pregnancy should have serum VDRL performed.
  • This is to check for congenital syphilis, as the transmission can occur transplacentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby: This would be indicated if the baby's serum VDRL is positive or if there are clinical signs of congenital syphilis, or if the mother's treatment was not adequate or uncertain.

 

Option C. Perform CSF VDRL of the baby: This is indicated if there is clinical evidence of neurosyphilis or if the serum VDRL is positive, suggesting congenital syphilis.

 

Option D. Wait and Watch: This approach is not recommended due to the risk of congenital syphilis which can have serious and irreversible consequences if not treated promptly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a newborn with a risk of congenital syphilis, a serum VDRL should be performed to screen for the disease.
  • If the test is positive or there are clinical signs suggestive of congenital syphilis, further treatment and investigations, including CSF analysis, are warranted to manage the condition appropriately.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a skin condition that has been present for several months. She reports that whenever she scratches her skin, even lightly, she develops raised, red lines that are itchy and last for about 30 minutes to an hour. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dermatographic urticaria

 

  • Dermatographic urticaria, also known as skin writing, is a condition in which light scratching or firm stroking of the skin causes raised, red lines where the person has scratched.
  • It is a form of physical urticaria where the skin becomes raised and inflamed when stroked, rubbed, or lightly scratched.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contact dermatitis: This condition causes a skin rash that occurs due to contact with an allergen or an irritant. It doesn't typically present as raised lines following scratching.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: A chronic autoimmune condition characterized by patches of abnormal skin. These are typically red, dry, itchy, and scaly, not transient lines following skin trauma.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis: Also known as eczema, it is a condition that makes the skin red and itchy but does not produce raised lines upon scratching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key feature of Dermatographic urticaria is the formation of raised, red lines on the skin in response to scratching, which typically resolve within an hour.

questions.text: During a routine shift, a medical officer at a district hospital is called to examine four deceased individuals, each with different medical histories and causes of death. The officer notes the early onset of rigor mortis in three cases but needs to determine which condition typically does not lead to an early onset of rigor mortis. Which of the following conditions is NOT associated with early onset of rigor mortis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumonia

 

  • Pneumonia does not generally lead to an early onset of rigor mortis. The progression of rigor mortis is typically influenced by the overall health of the muscles and the metabolic conditions prior to death.
  • In conditions like cholera, heat stroke, and OPC poisoning, there is often a significant depletion of ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate) due to increased muscle activity or extreme physiological stress, leading to an earlier onset of rigor mortis.
  • Pneumonia, being primarily a respiratory condition, does not inherently cause such metabolic conditions that expedite the onset of rigor mortis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholera: Leads to severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalance, which can cause faster depletion of ATP in muscle cells, hastening the onset of rigor mortis.

 

Option B. Heat stroke: Excessive body temperature can increase metabolic rate leading to quicker consumption of ATP, thereby accelerating the onset of rigor mortis.

 

Option C. OPC poisoning: Organophosphorus compounds inhibit acetylcholinesterase, causing continuous muscle contractions, which deplete ATP rapidly and cause an early onset of rigor mortis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rigor mortis (Latin, stiffness of death) is that state of the muscles in a dead body when they become stiff or rigid with some degree of shortening.
  • Conditions like cholera, heat stroke, and OPC poisoning accelerate rigor mortis, while pneumonia does not, is crucial for forensic investigations to help estimate the time of death more accurately.

choices.text: Fibre-optic laryngoscopy to rule out bilateral vocal cord paralysis
Administration of intravenous calcium

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of previous right thyroidectomy for a benign thyroid nodule now undergoes completion thyroidectomy for a suspicious thyroid mass. Several hours postoperatively, she develops progressive stridor, and difficulty breathing. Orotracheal intubation is successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wound exploration

 

  • The clinical presentation is consistent with a wound hematoma and necessitates exploration of the wound, drainage of the hematoma, and identification and control of any bleeding vessels.
  • If airway control is unable to be obtained prior to the operating room, the wound should be opened at the bedside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibre-optic laryngoscopy to rule out bilateral vocal cord paralysis: Bilateral vocal cord dysfunction can be a cause of postoperative stridor and difficulty breathing, particularly after re-operative surgery; however, bilateral vocal cord dysfunction should manifest immediately after extubation.

 

Option B. Administration of intravenous calcium: Hypocalcemia can occur in post-thyroidectomy due to ischemia or accidental removal of parathyroid tissue but it is typically transient. Symptoms of hypocalcemia are usually neuromuscular and cardiac in nature.

 

Option C. Nerve monitoring: Nerve monitoring helps in intra-operative identification of nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical picture of post-operative wound hematoma causing tracheal compressing, requiring immediate wound exploration and removal of clot.

questions.text: A 42-year woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhoea. Pelvis ultrasound reveals an intramural fibroid measuring 3 cm. The woman desires medical management rather than surgical intervention. Which of the following would be the most appropriate 1st line drug in this woman?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antifibrinolytic with NSAID

 

  • Antifibrinolytics, such as tranexamic acid, along with Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or naproxen, are commonly used as first-line medical management for heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea, even in the presence of uterine fibroids.
  • Tranexamic acid helps reduce menstrual blood loss by preventing the breakdown of blood clots, and NSAIDs can reduce menstrual flow and alleviate pain through their anti-inflammatory effects.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Combined estrogen-progesterone: Combined hormonal contraceptives can be effective in regulating the menstrual cycle and reducing bleeding and pain associated with fibroids. However, they are not typically considered the first-line treatment specifically for fibroid-related symptoms due to potential risks and side effects, especially in women over 35 who smoke or have certain medical conditions.

 

Option C. GnRH antagonist: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonists effectively reduce fibroid size and symptoms by inducing a hypoestrogenic state. However, due to potential side effects, including bone density loss with long-term use, they are not usually the first choice for initial management and are often used as a pre-surgical treatment to reduce fibroid size and vascularity.

 

Option D. Ulipristal acetate: Ulipristal acetate is a selective progesterone receptor modulator that can be used to treat moderate to severe symptoms of uterine fibroids. It is an effective medication for controlling bleeding and reducing fibroid size but may not always be the first-line choice due to considerations regarding the duration of use and potential liver toxicity with long-term treatment.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • In managing heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea associated with uterine fibroids, the first-line medical treatment often includes antifibrinolytics, such as tranexamic acid, combined with NSAIDs.
  • This approach aims to reduce menstrual blood loss and alleviate pain, offering an effective non-surgical option for symptom management.

choices.text: 10 mL/kg of hydroxyethyl starch
20 mL/kg of 0.45% normal saline
20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline

questions.text: In a 5-year-old child presenting with signs of sepsis and shock (BP 90/60 mm Hg, pulse rate 144/min, respiratory rate 30/min), which initial fluid management is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline

 

  • 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline is the fluid of choice for initial management of shock in children due to its isotonic nature, which helps to restore intravascular volume and improve perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 mL/kg of 10% dextrose: 10 mL/kg of 10% dextrose is typically not used for initial fluid resuscitation in shock as it does not contain electrolytes and does not expand intravascular volume effectively.

 

Option B. 10 mL/kg of hydroxyethyl starch: 10 mL/kg of hydroxyethyl starch is not the first-line fluid for pediatric shock due to concerns about increasing clotting times and kidney injury.

 

Option C. 20 mL/kg of 0.45% normal saline: 20 mL/kg of 0.45% normal saline, a hypotonic solution, is not appropriate for initial resuscitation as it might not adequately restore intravascular volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The initial management of pediatric shock involves rapid intravenous administration of isotonic fluids, such as 0.9% normal saline, at a dose of 20 mL/kg to restore intravascular volume and improve perfusion.

choices.text: Defective enzyme tyrosinase
Defective migration of melanocytes
External chemical destruction of melanocytes

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with several depigmented patches on her hands and face as shown in the image below. There were white hairs seen in the depigmented patches. These patches have progressively enlarged over the past year. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the depigmentation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absent melanocytes

 

  • The image and description are indicative of vitiligo, a condition characterized by depigmented patches on the skin due to the loss or destruction of melanocytes, the cells that produce melanin.
  • White hairs within the patches are a classic sign of vitiligo because the melanocytes in the hair follicles are also affected.
  • The presence of white hair (Leucotrichia) is indicative of a loss of melanocyte function in the hair follicles as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective enzyme tyrosinase: This is a characteristic of albinism, not vitiligo. In albinism, melanocytes are present, but there is a defect in the production of melanin due to the lack of the enzyme tyrosinase.

 

Option C. Defective migration of melanocytes: This could be seen in conditions like piebaldism, where there is a congenital absence of melanocytes in certain areas of the skin.

 

Option D. External chemical destruction of melanocytes: While chemicals can cause localized depigmentation, this is typically not progressive and does not lead to the white hairs seen in vitiligo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitiligo is an autoimmune disorder characterized by progressive depigmentation of the skin due to the loss of melanocytes.
  • The presence of white or depigmented hair within the patches is highly suggestive of vitiligo.

choices.text: A slight pressure may be applied at the cricoid cartilage to occlude the esophagus during rapid sequence induction.
After insertion of the laryngoscope, the blade is used to lift the tongue and soft tissues to visualize the vocal cords, without using teeth as a fulcrum.
The patient's neck should be positioned with flexion at the cervical spine and extension at the atlantooccipital joint, known as the 'sniffing position'.
The laryngoscope is usually held in the right hand and introduced from the right side of the patient’s mouth.

questions.text: While conducting laryngoscopy and intubation in a clinical skills examination, which of the following steps is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The laryngoscope is usually held in the right hand and introduced from the right side of the patient’s mouth.

 

The laryngoscope is typically held in the left hand and introduced from the right side of the patient’s mouth for both right-handed and left-handed operators, to maximize the view of the vocal cords and ease of intubation.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A slight pressure may be applied at the cricoid cartilage to occlude the esophagus during rapid sequence induction: Applying slight pressure at the cricoid cartilage, known as cricoid pressure or Sellick's maneuver, can help prevent aspiration during rapid sequence induction.

 

Option B. After insertion of the laryngoscope, the blade is used to lift the tongue and soft tissues to visualize the vocal cords, without using teeth as a fulcrum: While visualizing the vocal cords, the laryngoscope should be inserted into the mouth and used to lift the tongue and soft tissues upward, not levered on the upper incisors which could cause damage.

 

Option C. The patient's neck should be positioned with flexion at the cervical spine and extension at the atlantooccipital joint, known as the 'sniffing position': The 'sniffing position' is indeed the recommended posture for laryngoscopy and intubation, facilitating direct visualization of the vocal cords.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • It is important to recognize proper techniques during laryngoscopy and intubation, such as avoiding leveraging the laryngoscope on the patient's upper incisors, positioning the patient in the 'sniffing position', and holding the laryngoscope in the left hand while introducing it from the right side of the mouth.

choices.text: The patient had Dupuytren's Contracture
Palmar Aponeurosis is thickening of Deep Fascia of Palm
Each slip is attached to the Base of the Middle Phalanx and to the Fibrous Flexor Sheath of each finger
The Palmar Aponeurosis distally it divides into Four Slips

questions.text: A 54-year-old man had noticed during the past 3 months a thickening of the skin at the base of his right ring finger, which tried to pull his finger towards palm. He consulted his physician. On examination of the palms of both hands, a localized thickening of subcutaneous tissue could be felt at the base of the right ring and little fingers. The metacarpophalangeal joint of the ring finger could not be fully extended, either actively or passively. Identify the incorrect statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Each slip is attached to the Base of the Middle Phalanx and to the Fibrous Flexor Sheath of each finger

 

The palmar aponeurosis is thickening of the deep fascia of the palm. It is attached to the base of the proximal phalanx and fibrous flexor sheath of each finger.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient had Dupuytren's Contracture: Dupuytren's Contracture is characterized by progressive thickening and shortening of the palmar fascia, leading to flexion contractures of the fingers, commonly the ring and little fingers.

 

 

The symptoms described, including the thickening of the skin at the base of the ring finger and the inability to fully extend the metacarpophalangeal joint, align with Dupuytren's contracture.

 

Option B. Palmar Aponeurosis is thickening of Deep Fascia of Palm: The palmar aponeurosis is indeed a thickening of the deep fascia in the palm of the hand. It plays a key role in the structure and function of the hand, and its pathological thickening and contraction are central to Dupuytren's contracture.

 

Option D. The Palmar Aponeurosis distally it divides into Four Slips: The palmar aponeurosis distally divides into slips that extend towards the fingers. While the number of slips can vary, typically, it divides into four or five slips extending towards the digits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Each Slip is Attached to the Base of the Middle Phalanx and to the Fibrous Flexor Sheath of Each Finger: 
  • In Dupuytren's contracture, the pathological changes occur in the palmar aponeurosis and related structures.
  • However, the palmar aponeurosis does not normally attach to the base of the middle phalanx. Instead, it primarily attaches to the bases of the proximal phalanges and the overlying skin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department after ingesting a large quantity of an unknown substance in a suicide attempt. The medical team suspects poisoning and considers various detoxification methods. A forensic expert suggests charcoal hemoperfusion as a possible treatment. For which of the following poisonings is charcoal hemoperfusion most useful?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barbiturates

 

  • Charcoal hemoperfusion is particularly effective in cases of barbiturate poisoning.
  • This treatment involves passing the patient's blood through a column of activated charcoal, which adsorbs toxins, including barbiturates, effectively removing them from the bloodstream.
  • Barbiturates are lipophilic and are well adsorbed by charcoal, making hemoperfusion a suitable treatment option for rapid detoxification in acute poisoning scenarios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methanol: Treatment typically involves administration of fomepizole or ethanol, and hemodialysis to remove methanol and its toxic metabolites from the blood, rather than charcoal hemoperfusion.

 

Option C. Salicylate: While charcoal can adsorb salicylates if given orally as part of gastric decontamination, hemoperfusion is not the first-line treatment for salicylate poisoning, which often involves alkalization of urine and hemodialysis for severe cases.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Poisoning with digoxin is usually treated with digoxin-specific antibody fragments (digibind) and not by charcoal hemoperfusion, as digoxin is not effectively removed by charcoal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Charcoal hemoperfusion is particularly useful for removing lipophilic substances such as barbiturates from the bloodstream, which can be critical in managing acute poisoning cases effectively.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his penis. He reports a history of contact with a commercial sex worker. A dark-field microscopy examination of the discharge from the lesion was performed, and the results are shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chancre

 

  • The image from dark-field microscopy shows spirochetes, which are indicative of syphilis.
  • A painless ulcer (chancre) on the genitals is a classic presentation of primary syphilis.
  • The painless nature of the ulcer, the patient's sexual history, and the appearance of the spirochetes on dark-field microscopy support the diagnosis of a chancre due to primary syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chancroid: Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, chancroid presents with a painful ulcer and may have a purulent base but does not show spirochetes on dark-field microscopy.

 

Option C. Herpes: Genital herpes, caused by the herpes simplex virus, presents with painful vesicles or ulcers and would not show spirochetes under the microscope.

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale: Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, this condition presents with beefy-red granulomatous ulcers without lymphadenopathy and does not exhibit spirochetes on microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clue for diagnosis: Painless ulcer on penis, h/o contact with commercial sex worker, Dark ground microscopy showing spirally coiled bacilli à Suggestive of Treponema pallidum

choices.text: Establish an intravenous line and begin saline infusion
Perform needle decompression on the right side of the chest
Proceed to immediate tracheostomy

questions.text: A pregnant woman arrives at the emergency department after suffering a stab wound to the right chest. She is extremely anxious and vocal. Vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension (90/60 mm Hg), with diminished breath sounds on the right and dullness on percussion. What should be the first step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Establish an intravenous line and begin saline infusion

 

  • In the setting of trauma with signs of decreased breath sounds, dullness and hypotension, the scenario suggests a massive hemothorax.
  • In this case, IVF should be started to restore the hemodynamic status.
  • Establishing an IV line and beginning saline infusion are important for resuscitation in this case.

 

Option A. Oropharyngeal airway: An oropharyngeal airway may be used to maintain a patent airway, but the patient is conscious and shouting, indicating a clear airway.

 

Option C. Perform needle decompression on the right side of the chest: Needle decompression on the right side of the chest is indicated to treat a suspected tension pneumothorax, which is unlikely the case here.

 

Option D. Proceed to immediate tracheostomy: Immediate tracheostomy is not indicated at this time as the airway is not compromised.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the setting of trauma with signs of decreased breath sounds, dullness and hypotension, the scenario suggests a massive hemothorax. In this case, IVF should be started to restore the hemodynamic status.

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML)
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, generalized weakness, weight loss, pancytopenia, and palpable lymph nodes. The peripheral smear is as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ALL

 

  • The peripheral smear shows large cells with a high nucleo-cytoplasmic ratio, prominent nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm characteristic of ALL.
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is characterized by the presence of lymphoblasts in the peripheral blood and bone marrow and can present with these clinical features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML): It is a chronic leukemia that typically presents with monocytosis, organomegaly, and skin rash rather than blasts.

 

Option C. Aplastic anemia: Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia and absence of reticulocytes, but blasts are not usually seen on the smear.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) could present similarly, but the peripheral smear would typically show myeloblasts with Auer rods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of lymphoblasts in the peripheral smear in a child with fever, pancytopenia, and lymphadenopathy is characteristic of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

choices.text: It is located on the dorsal aspect of hand and becomes visible when the thumb is fully abducted adducted
Floor is formed by styloid process of radius, base of first metacarpal bone
Medially by tendon of extensor pollicis brevis
Laterally by extensor carpi radialis longus

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect about the pointed Area A in the given image except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Floor is formed by styloid process of radius, base of first metacarpal bone

 

  • The pointed area A in the given image is Anatomical Snuff Box (ASB)
  • All the statements given are incorrect except option B.
  • Floor of ASB is formed by-
    • Styloid Process of Radius
    • Scaphoid
    • Trapezium
    • Base of 1st Metacarpal

 

OTHER OPTIONS:

 

Option A. It is located on the dorsal aspect of hand and becomes visible when the thumb is fully abducted adducted: This statement is incorrect. The anatomical snuffbox is located on the dorsal (back) aspect of the hand and becomes more prominent when the thumb is hyperextended.

 

 

Option C. Medially by tendon of extensor pollicis brevis: This statement is incorrect. The medial border or boundary of the anatomical snuffbox is indeed formed by the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus muscle. This muscle plays a role in extending the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

 

 

Option D. Laterally by extensor carpi radialis longus: This statement is also incorrect. The lateral border or boundary of the anatomical snuffbox is indeed formed by the tendon of the abductor pollicis longus and Extensor pollicis brevis. This muscle extends the wrist and abducts the hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Floor is formed by the styloid process of the radius and the base of the first metacarpal bone:
  • This statement is correct. From proximal to distal floor is formed by the styloid process of radius, scaphoid, trapezium and base of first metacarpal bone. Radial artery crosses the floor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented to a physician with complaints of hematuria. Upon evaluation, red blood cells (RBCs) were found in the urine but no medical cause was identified. Further inquiry revealed that she has visited many doctors with the same complaints and would demand inpatient care. She would prick her finger and mix blood in the urine sample. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factitious illness

 

  • Factitious illness, also known as Factitious Disorder Imposed on Self, involves a person intentionally producing or feigning physical or psychological symptoms for no apparent gain except possibly to assume the sick role and receive medical attention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malingering: This involves fabricating or exaggerating symptoms for a secondary gain such as financial benefit or avoidance of work.

 

Option C. Dissociative disorder: This mental disorder involves a disruption of normal consciousness, memory, identity, or perception and is not associated with the intentional production of symptoms.

 

Option D. Hypochondriasis (Illness Anxiety Disorder): This condition is characterized by excessive worry about having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms and without intentionally producing symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Factitious disorder is a condition where patients intentionally produce symptoms to assume the sick role, typically without external incentives, a crucial distinction for appropriate psychiatric referral and management

questions.text: A child is presenting defect in lower limbs as shown below likely has a metabolic defect impacting the urea cycle. Which enzyme deficiency should be suspected in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arginase

 

  • Arginase deficiency can lead to hyperargininemia, which uniquely presents later in childhood with progressive spastic diplegia, rather than early-life hyperammonemic crises.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ornithine transcarbamoylase: Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency typically presents with hyperammonemia, particularly in males due to its X-linked inheritance pattern.

 

Option B. Carbamoyl phosphate synthase 1: Carbamoyl phosphate synthase 1 deficiency results in hyperammonemia type 1 and is considered one of the most severe urea cycle disorders.

 

Option D. Ornithine permease: Ornithine permease deficiency leads to the hyperornithinemia-hyperammonemia-homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome due to impaired ornithine transport into mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arginase deficiency causes hyperargininemia, typically presenting between ages 2 and 4 with spastic diplegia and increased levels of arginine, distinct from the early-onset hyperammonemia seen in other urea cycle disorders.

choices.text: Blood supply to sole is from branches of posterior tibial artery
Lateral plantar artery is the larger terminal branch and forms the plantar arterial arch
Plantar arterial arch will give rise to four plantar metatarsal arteries
Plantar arterial arch lies between the second & third layer of sole

questions.text: A 23-year-old female, manual labourer at a construction site, accidentally stepped over a sharp-edged blade in the site, following which there was severe bleeding from her sole. She was taken to a nearby hospital, where with much difficulty, the bleeding was arrested and cut ends were sutured. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plantar arterial arch lies between the second & third layer of sole

 

  • The trunks of neurovascular bundles lie between the first & second layer of the sole.
  • In the context of a severe foot injury involving significant bleeding in the sole, understanding the vascular anatomy of the foot is crucial.

 

 

Other Options:
