Option A. Blood supply to sole is from branches of posterior tibial artery: The sole of the foot primarily receives its blood supply from branches of the posterior tibial artery. The posterior tibial artery, after passing posterior to the medial malleolus, enters the sole of the foot where it divides into the medial and lateral plantar arteries.

 

Option B. Lateral plantar artery is the larger terminal branch and forms the plantar arterial arch: The lateral plantar artery, a terminal branch of the posterior tibial artery, is indeed the larger of the two terminal branches. It curves medially on the sole of the foot, forming the plantar arterial arch. This arch plays a critical role in supplying blood to the plantar surface of the foot.

 

Option C. Plantar arterial arch will give rise to four plantar metatarsal arteries: The plantar arterial arch typically gives rise to four plantar metatarsal arteries. These arteries further divide into digital branches to supply the toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The plantar arterial arch lies deep to the tendons of the flexor digitorum brevis, which is in the second layer of the sole. It does not lie between the second and third layers but rather deep to the second layer.

choices.text: Administer 100% oxygen to offset the second gas effect
Administer 100% oxygen to prevent diffusion hypoxia
Administer 100% oxygen to ensure adequate analgesia during recovery
Administer 100% oxygen because it is less expensive than air

questions.text: A patient is emerging from anesthesia that included the use of nitrous oxide. To prevent a common post-anesthetic complication, which practice is typically followed by anesthesiologists?
questions.solution:
Ans. B). Administer 100% oxygen to prevent diffusion hypoxia.

 

  • The second gas effect is a phenomenon whereby the uptake of one gas (e.g., nitrous oxide) increases the uptake of a second gas (e.g., a volatile anesthetic).
  • Administering 100% oxygen on emergence does not directly relate to the second gas effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Administer 100% oxygen to prevent diffusion hypoxia: Diffusion hypoxia can occur after discontinuation of nitrous oxide if 100% oxygen is not administered. Nitrous oxide diffuses out of the blood into the alveoli, diluting the concentration of oxygen and possibly leading to hypoxia. Administering 100% oxygen replenishes alveolar oxygen and prevents this scenario.

 

Option C. Administer 100% oxygen to ensure adequate analgesia during recovery: While oxygen has mild analgesic properties, administering 100% oxygen after nitrous oxide use is not primarily for analgesia but rather to prevent diffusion hypoxia.

 

Option D. Administer 100% oxygen because it is less expensive than air: The cost of air versus oxygen is not a consideration in the decision to administer 100% oxygen after nitrous oxide use. The priority is patient safety and the prevention of hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Administering 100% oxygen after the use of nitrous oxide in anesthesia is essential to prevent diffusion hypoxia, a condition where the rapid diffusion of nitrous oxide out of the blood dilutes alveolar oxygen and leads to a decrease in available oxygen for the patient.

questions.text: When evaluating the role of endotoxins in the pathogenesis of infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria, a group of researchers analyzes several species to determine which one's endotoxin does not contribute to the natural disease process. Which of the following Gram-negative bacteria is known for a pathogenesis in which the endotoxin plays no role?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio cholera

 

  • Vibrio cholera also possess lipopolysaccharide O antigen (LPS, endotoxin) as in other gram-negative intestinal bacilli. But unlike other gram-negative bacilli like E. coli, Klebsiella and Pseudomonas, etc. (where endotoxin is the principle virulence factor), LPS apparently plays no role in pathogenesis of cholera but is responsible for the immunity induced by killed vaccine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli: Certain strains produce endotoxins that contribute to the pathology of diseases like hemorrhagic colitis.

 

Option B. Klebsiella: Endotoxin is a significant virulence factor in Klebsiella infections, contributing to symptoms in infections such as pneumonia.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas aeruginosa's endotoxin plays a role in its pathogenesis, contributing to inflammation and septic shock in severe infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vibrio cholerae's disease mechanism is primarily due to its exotoxin rather than its endotoxin is critical in comprehending the pathophysiology of cholera and the massive fluid loss it causes.

choices.text: Termination of the pregnancy followed by modified radical mastectomy
Immediate administration of chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy after delivery of the baby
Breast conservation therapy in third trimester
Modified radical mastectomy

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman notices a persistent, painless lump in the left breast. On examination the left breast has a single mobile mass without evidence of skin changes or lymphadenopathy in the neck or axilla. An ultrasound demonstrates a solid, 1-cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. A core-needle biopsy shows invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient is in her first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified radical mastectomy

 

The most appropriate treatment is immediate surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Termination of the pregnancy followed by modified radical mastectomy: There is no evidence that general anesthesia and nonabdominal surgery increase premature labour and therefore surgery should not be delayed until after delivery of the baby.

 

Option B. Immediate administration of chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy after delivery of the baby: Administration of chemotherapy to a pregnant patient should be delayed until after the first trimester due to the increased risk of fetal abnormalities. Chemotherapy does not appear to increase the risk of congenital malformation when given in the second or third trimester of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Breast conservation therapy in third trimester: Breast conservation therapy is not routinely recommended during pregnancy because the radioactivity may harm the fetus. Radiation therapy is contraindicated in all trimesters of pregnancy. Patients in later stages of pregnancy, however, can start radiation therapy shortly after delivery, and some may be candidates for breast-conserving surgery and adjuvant radiotherapy.

 

Educational objective:

 

Elective termination of the pregnancy to receive appropriate therapy without the risk to the fetus is no longer routinely recommended because it has not been demonstrated to improve survival.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed to have endometrial carcinoma on biopsy. She wishes to understand the high-risk factors for development of endometrial cancer. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for development of endometrial carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiparity

 

  • Multiparity (having given birth to more than one child) is generally not considered a risk factor for endometrial carcinoma.
  • In fact, having multiple full-term pregnancies is often thought to be protective against the development of endometrial cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetes: Women with diabetes, especially type 2, are at a higher risk for developing endometrial cancer. Insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia, common in type 2 diabetes, are thought to contribute to this increased risk.

 

Option C. Obesity: Obesity is a well-known risk factor for endometrial cancer. Excess body fat can lead to increased estrogen levels, which, in the absence of progesterone, can stimulate the endometrial lining and increase the risk of cancer.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen therapy: Tamoxifen is a medication used primarily to treat and prevent breast cancer. However, one of its side effects is an increased risk of endometrial cancer. Tamoxifen has estrogenic effects on the uterine lining, which can lead to endometrial hyperplasia and, potentially, cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When discussing risk factors for endometrial carcinoma, it's important to recognize that multiparity is generally not associated with an increased risk of this type of cancer.
  • In fact, having multiple pregnancies is often considered to be protective.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female with severe Inflammatory Arthritis and on long term medications for treatment of Osteoporosis suddenly presented in emergency with pain in thigh with Inability to ambulate. X Rays were performed as below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atypical Fracture

 

  • Atypical fractures are associated with long-term bisphosphonate therapy for osteoporosis.
  • These fractures occur with minimal or no trauma and are located in the subtrochanteric region or femoral shaft.
  • They often present as transverse or short oblique fractures, and patients may report prodromal pain in the weeks to months before the fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Typical Subtrochanteric Fracture: Typical Subtrochanteric Fracture Typical subtrochanteric fractures usually result from high-energy trauma and present with a different fracture pattern compared to atypical fractures. They tend to be comminuted and associated with a history of significant injury.

 

Option C. Paget’s Disease of Bone: Paget’s Disease of Bone Paget’s disease of bone presents with enlarged and misshapen bones, usually affecting the pelvis, skull, spine, and legs. While it can lead to fractures, the X-ray findings typically show thickened bone trabeculae and cortical changes distinct from those in atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Malignancy of the Bone: Bone malignancies often present with lytic or blastic lesions on X-ray, pathological fractures, and localized bone pain. The pain is typically persistent and progresses over time, often worse at night. In the absence of these characteristic findings, malignancy is less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation and radiographic features of an atypical femoral fracture, particularly in the context of a patient with osteoporosis undergoing long-term bisphosphonate therapy are characterized by specific radiographic features such as a transverse orientation, absence of comminution, and location in the subtrochanteric or diaphyseal region of the femur.

choices.text: Iliofemoral Ligament: Prevents Hyperextension of the Hip Joint
Ischiofemoral Ligament: Prevents Excessive Lateral Rotation of the Hip Joint
Pubofemoral Ligament: Limits Abduction and External Rotation of the Hip Joint
Ligamentum Teres: Primary Stabilizer of the Hip Joint in all Movements

questions.text: A third-year medical student is studying the anatomy of the hip joint for an upcoming exam. Which of the following ligaments is correctly paired with its primary function in stabilizing the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iliofemoral Ligament: Prevents Hyperextension of the Hip Joint

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ischiofemoral Ligament: Prevents Excessive Lateral Rotation of the Hip Joint: Ischiofemoral ligament is located posteriorly and primarily limits excessive internal rotation and extension of the hip joint.

 

Option C. Pubofemoral Ligament: Limits Abduction and External Rotation of the Hip Joint: Pubofemoral ligament extends from the pubic portion of the acetabular rim to the neck of the femur. It restricts excessive abduction and external rotation of the hip joint, making this statement partially correct. However, its primary role is in limiting excessive abduction.

 

Option D. Ligamentum Teres: Primary Stabilizer of the Hip Joint in all Movements: Ligamentum teres is relatively weak and does not play a significant role in stabilizing the hip joint. Its primary role is to carry a small artery to the head of the femur, rather than act as a stabilizer.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iliofemoral ligament: This is the strongest ligament in the body and prevents hyperextension of the hip joint.
  • It is located anteriorly and is often referred to as the Y-ligament of Bigelow.
